summary: This document is a chain of emails from March 2020 between SDNY prosecutors and administrative staff regarding travel approval requests for the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The primary request is for urgent travel to London to interview a key witness, Emmy Taylor, the former assistant to Ghislaine Maxwell. The emails also reference prior travel for interviews in Sweden, Los Angeles, and West Palm Beach.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.context: Recipient and approver of multiple travel approval requests from the prosecution team for the Epstein investigation. He grants final approval for travel.

persons.name: Darlene Alleyne
persons.context: Copied on travel approval request emails, appears to be an administrative point of contact.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Primary author of the travel requests, leading the effort to interview witnesses including Emmy Taylor. Provides detailed justifications for the trips.

persons.name: Emmy Taylor
persons.role: Former Assistant to Ghislaine Maxwell, Key Witness
persons.context: Described as a potentially critical witness located in the UK. She was Ghislaine Maxwell's former assistant and was allegedly present during instances of sexual abuse.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Identified as the 'current top target subject' of the investigation. Emmy Taylor was her former assistant.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Identified as the person who replaced Emmy Taylor as Maxwell's assistant. Described as 'the only other individual we currently are considering charging.'

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: Member of the prosecution team traveling for witness interviews. Has a valid official passport.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Member of the prosecution team traveling for witness interviews in West Palm Beach and Los Angeles.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: Copied on some of the earlier travel approval request emails from 2019.

connections.description: Taylor was the former assistant to Maxwell, working for her for years during a key period under investigation.
Sarah Kellen replaced Emmy Taylor as Ghislaine Maxwell's assistant.
Alex (AUSA) is requesting travel approval from supervisor Edward Tyrrell.
Both are members of the prosecution team traveling together for interviews.
Both are members of the prosecution team traveling together for interviews.

events.title: Planned Interview with Emmy Taylor in London
events.description: The prosecution team seeks urgent approval to travel to London to interview key witness Emmy Taylor, former assistant to Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Planned Interview in Stockholm, Sweden
events.description: The team requested travel to Sweden for an interview near Stockholm.

events.title: Planned Interview(s) in Los Angeles
events.description: The team requested travel to Los Angeles for an interview or interviews.

events.title: Interview in West Palm Beach
events.description: The team (Alex and Maurene) requested travel to West Palm Beach, Florida for an interview.

events.title: Approved Travel for Meetings in West Palm Beach
events.description: Edward Tyrrell approved travel for Alison and Alex to West Palm Beach for meetings and interviews related to United States v. Epstein.

keyFacts: Prosecutors identified Emmy Taylor, Ghislaine Maxwell's former assistant, as a potentially 'most critical' witness who was present during instances of sexual abuse and could be the only witness to that conduct other than the victim.
Sarah Kellen, who replaced Emmy Taylor as Maxwell's assistant, is identified as 'the only other individual we currently are considering charging' besides Maxwell.
The prosecution team was actively pursuing international travel to interview Taylor in London in March 2020, despite Coronavirus concerns, due to her perceived unique importance to the case.
The investigation is referred to as 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618, an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity.'

The email chain reveals a pattern of frequent travel by the SDNY prosecution team in 2019-2020 to interview victims and witnesses in multiple locations including Florida, California, Sweden, and the UK.
